1.text: ([i]Doki Doki Full Blossom Love: When the Holy Flower Blooms Under Clouded Skies…[/i] Or just [i]Full Blossom[/i] for short.)

2.text: (A visual novel where you play as the newly awakened Saintess, bringing hope back to a kingdom on the brink of collapse—and in the process, find love with one of three eligible bachelors.)

3.text: (It’s a tried and true formula, classic for its genre. Back in middle school, you had even considered it [i]peak[/i] fiction.)

4.text: (Now though? Well, you’re not too sure if you could trust that opinion.)

5.text: (It’s been years since you’d actually played it. Finding the cartridge while you were cleaning out your room was pure happenstance.)

6.text: (Maybe it was nostalgia, or maybe just the anxiety of knowing that you’d be moving out to college come next year. Either way, you couldn’t help the urge to blow the dust off and see what exactly made you so crazy for this game when you were a preteen.)

7.text: (So here you are now, walking over to the local grocery store to pick up some things for the week and burning the travel time with a game you have only the most threadbare memories of.)

9.text: (The handheld comes to life, and an elegant orchestral arrangement you could recite by heart sounds from your earbuds. You hum the lyrics quietly to yourself, paying no mind to the hustle and bustle around you on the crowded sidewalk.)

10.text: (You almost forgot how good the soundtrack is.)

11.text: (How many times had you played this game again?)

12.text: (…Too many times it seems. Obviously enough to lose count.)

13.text: (And yet, you can only remember the skeleton of the story and its characters.)

14.text: (Figures, middle school was never something you [i]ever[/i] want to remember. This game was probably just a casualty of that grudge.)

16.text: (You stare at the screen. A familiar face looks back up at you, smiling patiently.)

17.text: (It’s the heroine, still as pretty and perfect as ever.)

18.text: (Platinum blonde locks frame her face, cascading down her shoulders and back like a waterfall of light. Everything about her screams “Saintess.”)

19.text: (From her pale skin to her pale hair and her pale clothing broken up only by red beading that matches the perpetual rosy flush on her cheeks, she’s like a freshly bloomed lily who has yet to feel the warmth of the sun its petals twist and reach towards.)

22.text: (A prompt opens up. She needs a name.)

24.text: (Well, she doesn’t [i]need[/i] a name. She already has one by default.)

25.text: (On all the official merchandise she goes by “Seraphina Dolorosa,” a name befitting of such a pure and kindhearted character who goes through the absolute worst things a romance game can offer. All par for the course.)

26.text: ([i]Seraphina…[/i] You could just leave it and keep it this time.)

30.text: (You’re distracted, so you don’t see it coming.)

32.text: (Everyone else does though. They scramble out of the way from the speeding truck, its frantic horn blaring a plea from the driver for others to evacuate.)

33.text: (It’s the only thing he can do as the vehicle skids out of his control.)

34.text: (Those who aren’t paying attention have someone to pull them back: friends, family, fellow pedestrians; Someone to keep them safe.)

36.text: (Nothing registers. At least, not at first.)

37.text: (It’s a cold winter’s day. Small white flakes fall from over your head, dusting the slick ground in a fine white powder, the fluffy layers building with each passing moment.)

38.text: (That’s right, it was supposed to snow today, wasn’t it?)

39.text: (You guess that you must have forgotten.)

40.text: (The snow around you is soft, seeping into your clothes and melting into icy droplets as it finally makes contact with skin.)

41.text: (You weren’t wearing much to begin with. You should be freezing right now.)

42.text: (So why is it that you feel so warm? Warm enough to be lulled into a peaceful sleep by what feels like soothing waves and ripples beneath you.)

45.text: (If you sleep then you won’t have to feel it. The unbearable pain that comes to a boil beneath you as you lie on the iced over road.)

46.text: (You won’t have to see it; thick crimson red that drips down your face and catches in your eyelashes, stinging.)

47.options: Sleep won't make me face it.

48.text: (You won’t even remember what it’s like to choke on that acrid scent of smoke and burnt hair.)

49.options: I don't want to face any of it.

51.text: (It doesn’t feel like your eyes are open, but they are. The black void surrounding you plays tricks on your mind, making it feel like you’re still asleep.)

53.text: (You turn around… and jump back when you come face to face with another body.)

55.text: (You can barely process the fact that you’re staring at [i]something,[/i] but whenever you try to look further, your eyes unfocus, like something’s blocking them… like [b][i]it’s[/i][/b] not letting you.)

56.text: (Its one distinguishing feature that it allows you to make out is a wide, grinning set of teeth.)

58.text: A life barely lived, felled in an instant.

59.text: It makes one wonder what could have become of you. What has the world lost now with your life snuffed out with less than a moment’s notice?

60.text: Hah… You know how to leave someone craving for more. Enough that my eye was caught by your plight.

61.text: (It sits back, resting its chin on one propped up hand.)

62.text: (Even without a full face, it seems amused.)

63.text: Feel honored, human. Few intrigue me enough to give them my full attention.

64.text: And yet, ironically enough, I’ve found that you leave little to remark on. Even in your final moments you let slip what little consciousness you had remaining, like loose sand through a shattered hourglass.

66.text: (The being looks away, seemingly in deep thought. It appears to be watching something only it can see, though you have a feeling that whatever it is is somehow connected to you.)

67.text: It won’t be long until the falling snow washes away any memory of your passing.

68.text: Who am I? Well… I am a creator, a judge, a lover of stories. I am power and change.

69.text: My domain looks over all as I entertain myself over matters of the mortal.

71.text: [i]So I suppose you would call me a god.[/i]

72.text: You are dead. Well, your body is at least.

73.text: I assume you needed those suspicions confirmed, did you not? Mortals always do.

74.text: (It nonchalantly waves a hand at the empty space that surrounds the two of you.)

75.text: This is the final boundary before true death, a land that falls outside of my own jurisdiction. Thus, I intercepted you here.

76.text: [i]I couldn’t let you go just yet.[/i]

77.text: No, that simply will not do. My time may be infinite, but even a moment of it is worth more than anything you could achieve in an eternity.

78.text: (Even if you want to speak, to reject and question all you've been told, you can’t. Your mouth won’t let you, an invisible force holding it firmly shut.)

79.text: (The being looks down on you, and you feel absolutely powerless pinned under its gaze.)

80.text: (There is no hate. No love. Just unrelenting power.)

81.text: (You are nothing in the eyes of this… this [i]god.[/i])

82.text: You have been met with such a tragic fate, haven’t you? A green bud pruned before its first petal could even emerge.

83.text: It is your type that I pity most.

84.text: (It says this, but you feel no warmth in the words. It’s like it’s not even talking to you.)

85.text: But… that is why I have decided to present you with a choice. A second chance if you will.

88.text: [b]One.[/b] You may move on, like all the others before you.

89.text: Your soul will relinquish the memories it accumulated in this life, and move on to face whatever death holds for it.

90.text: The specifics of that though, even I am unable to reveal.

92.text: [b]Two.[/b] An option which I do not give to many others, is that you may keep your memories, though not your original body.

93.text: Should you accept my deal, you will be born into another vessel in another world and be able to start anew. You will reawaken as someone different from yourself.

95.text: (The god hums. It looks awfully pleased with itself.)

96.text: Do not worry. I have reason to believe that you will enjoy this world immensely.

97.text: After all, you may be more familiar with it than you realize.

98.text: (Your eyes widen as the god snaps its fingers and a blurry vision appears. Enough to make out certain things, but not enough to confidently know where you are.)

99.text: (Sprawling estates, elegantly dressed passerby, contraptions that seem like they could never feasibly work but just do.)

100.text: (It’s like something straight out of a fantasy story you’d read and inevitably get way too attached to.)

101.text: (The god tilts its head and smiles triumphantly at the look on your face.)

102.text: Kekeke… Isn’t this [i]fun?[/i] You get a chance to live again, and in a world of your dreams no less!

103.text: I have just the body for you too. She’s a special one, though lately her end has left me wanting for more.

104.text: I’m sure you could bring some entertainment for me should you accept to reawaken as her.

105.text: (A special one… what does that mean?)

106.text: (It said something about “accepting a deal” earlier, didn’t it? If so, then… what could it possibly stand to gain from this?)

107.text: (The god’s soft laughter pulls you from your thoughts.)

109.text: (It doesn’t elaborate further. However, it does seem your suspicions have caught its attention.)

110.text: (Another shot at life… It seems too good to be true.)

111.text: So what do you say? Move on, or live on?

113.text: (This is your chance. A chance to be someone else. Someone better. A part of something bigger than yourself.)

114.text: (If you’re reborn again, then your original death will have been worth it, wouldn’t it?)

116.text: (Before you can give your answer, the god speaks again. Its voice has grown serious, the lower register a subtle reminder of the heavy choice that lies before you. You still don’t know for sure what you’re dealing with.)

117.text: ([i]...What if the costs are too great?[/i])

118.text: (An involuntary shiver runs down your spine at its sharp whisper.)

119.text: I may have been teasing you, but understand that no one, not even me, can interfere in your decision. Do not think that there is a right or wrong answer.

120.text: My offer is just that, an offer, opportunities and consequences included.

121.text: Perhaps true death may bring you better happiness than another chance ever could.

123.text: I won’t rush you, so take your time. Take an eternity if you need to.

124.text: I’ve entertained myself enough to spare you this.

125.text: The choice is completely and solely yours.

126.text: (Time stretches out between the two of you. Endless.)

127.text: (You don’t know how long you’ve stood here, mulling over the proposition. Minutes? Years?)

128.text: (However long it’s been, you think that you’ve finally made up your mind.)

129.text: Ready? Well then, let’s hear it.

130.options: I don't want this.,I want this. Let me become someone else.

132.text: Say your name. One final time. Relinquish it to me so that you may reawaken, born anew.

134.text: (You open your mouth, and a name falls from your lips—falls away from you and scatters to the winds.)

137.text: (Out from the darkness, shards of color materialize. They fly towards you at dizzying speeds, wrapping around your body, squeezing you tighter and tighter until it feels like only your bare essence is left.)

138.text: (You manage one last look at the god through a gap in your binding.)

139.text: (It leaves you with a final warning.)

sleep.text: (You won’t flinch away from the screams that ring in your ears, begging you to do something that you can’t quite process; won’t have to taste that bitter metallic sludge that forces its way up your throat and dribbles from your lips.)

face.text: (And so, you choose to sleep instead.)

who.text: (It answers before you even have a chance to ask the question.)

where.text: (The being looks at your confused expression and hums.)

passed.text: I am sure you have many more questions, but I have no desire to lounge around and humor them.

dontwant.text: Fair enough. I wish you peace, mortal. Whatever that may be.
